case_name: M/s. Kelvinator of India Ltd. v. State of Haryana

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2005 of 1972 filed by special leave against order dated 11th April 1972 of Punjab and Haryana High Court in General Sales Tax Reference No. 8 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2005  NT  of 1972. Appeal by special leave from the order dated the 11th April 1972 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court at Chandigarh, in General Sales Tax Reference No. 8 of 1970.

facts.text: Matter relates to assessment year 1965-66, period from April 1, 1965 to March 31, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: The matter relates to the assessment year 1965-66, i.e. the period from April 1, 1965 to March 31, 1966.

facts.text: Appellant Ms. Kelvinator of India Ltd. has factory at Faridabad in Haryana manufacturing refrigerators, deep freezers, compressors.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companypany has a, factory at Faridabad in Haryana. It manufactures refrigerators, deep freezers, companypressors and other similar articles.

facts.text: Appellant's registered office and sales office at 19A Alipore Road, Delhi, with godowns in Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: Its registered office and sales office are at 19A Alipore Road, Delhi. The appellant has godowns in Delhi having full staff of godown keepers and clerks.

facts.text: Appellant entered distribution agreement with Spencer & Co. Ltd. on April 26, 1965 for Kelvinator products, effective from April 1, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: On April 26, 1965 the appellant entered into a distribution agreement with Spencer Co. Ltd. in respect of refrigerators and other products having Kelvinator trade mark.

facts.text: Distribution agreement with Blue Star Engineering Co., Bombay Pvt. Ltd. on September 15, 1965 for Leonard refrigerators.

anchor.surface_text: Similar distribution agreements were entered into with Blue Star Engineering Co.  Bombay  Pvt. Ltd., on September 15, 1965 in respect of Leonard refrigerators

facts.text: Distribution agreement with General Equipment Merchants Ltd. on December 11, 1965 for Gem refrigerators.

anchor.surface_text: and on December 11, 1965 with General Equipment Merchants Ltd. in respect of Gem refrigerators.

facts.text: Agreements provide that goods delivered to distributors from company's registered office in Delhi, property passes in Delhi on delivery.

anchor.surface_text: The goods shall, be delivered to the Distributors from the Companys registered office in Delhi and the, property in the same shall pass to the Distributors in Delhi on delivery, where the sale shall always take place.

facts.text: Distributors pay transport charges from Faridabad to Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The Distributors shall also pay to the Company all the charges on the transport of the goods from the Companys works at Faridabad to the Companys Registered Office in Delhi.

facts.text: Goods moved from Faridabad factory to Delhi godowns prior to specific orders from distributors.

anchor.surface_text: The buyer places its specific order according to its requirement and to the extent goods are available at Delhi, delivery is given by the Delhi office after the goods are approved in good companydition by the purchaser.

facts.text: Excise clearance for movement from Faridabad to Delhi in favour of self, octroi paid by company.

anchor.surface_text: That after the goods are I manufactured in the factory an excise clearance pass is obtained after payment of excise duty for the transport of goods from the factory to the companypanys godown in Delhi. The excise pass is always for movement of goods in favour of self.

facts.text: Orders placed by distributors after inspecting goods in Delhi godowns, delivery and billing from Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: That in pursuance of the said orders Delhi staff givedelivery of the, goods at Delhi to the customer under a challan prepared at Delhi. That thereafter the bill is raised from Delhi and price of thegoods is received by the Company at Delhi

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer assessed inter-State sales tax at Rs. 8,14,112.25 on March 2, 1968, reduced to Rs. 1,59,691.19 on review.

anchor.surface_text: The assessing authority vide its order dated March 2, 1968 held ,that the transactions between the parties were inter- State sales and liable to be taxed as such. ... Subsequently on review ,application the tax liability was reduced to Rs. 1,59,691.19.

facts.text: Deputy Excise and Taxation Commissioner on appeal dated July 24, 1968 held agreements not contracts of sale, not inter-State sales.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal filed by the appellant, the-Deputy Excise and Taxation Commissioner as per order dated July 24, 1968 held that the distribution agreements were number companytracts of sale.

facts.text: Excise and Taxation Commissioner suo motu revised on September 12, 1968 holding appropriation at manufacture, inter-State sales.

anchor.surface_text: The Excise and Taxation Commissioner thereafter took suo motu action and after hearing both the parties he held as per order dated September 12, 1968 that as soon as the refrigerators were manufactured they were appropriated to the companytracts

facts.text: Sales Tax Tribunal on August 14, 1969 held agreements of sale, inter-State sales; review dismissed November 24, 1969.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal as per order dated August 14, 1969 took the view that the agreements with the distributors were agreements of sale and that the sales in question were inter-State sales. The ap- pellant thereafter filed review application but the same was dismissed by the Tribunal on November 24, 1969.

facts.text: High Court answered question in favour of department on April 11, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in answering the question in favour of the department found that the machines moved from Faridabad to Delhi in pursuance of agreements of sale which had been termed distribution agreements.

facts.text: Supreme Court held distribution agreements not contracts of sale, movement not occasioned by sale, sales local in Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the three agreements between the appellant and the distributors were merely agreements for the distribution of goods and were number agreements of sale between the parties. It cannot, in our opinion, be said that there was any movement of refrigerators from Faridabad to Delhi under a companytract of sale.

facts.text: No specific number of refrigerators or fixed price in agreements; prices mutually agreed from time to time.

anchor.surface_text: It is numbereworthy in this companytext to observe that the number of refrigerators which were to be purchased by each of the distributors was number specified in the distribution agreements, number did the agreements companytain the price which was to be charged for each refrigerator.

facts.text: Goods insured warehouse to warehouse by appellant, octroi paid by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companypany took a policy of insurance to companyer lorry risk as per Motor Lorry Risk clauses... It may also be mentioned in this companytext that the octroi charges in companynection with the movement of refrigerators from Faridabad to Delhi were paid by the appellant.

facts.text: Refrigerators identical except name plates, which are interchangeable; no appropriation at Faridabad.

anchor.surface_text: The three different brands of refrigerators were in all respects identical except in respect of the name plate. The said name plates, it has been demonstrated to us,. are easily interchangeable.

facts.text: In 1964, entire sales to Spencer accepted as genuine, not inter-State by department.

anchor.surface_text: The entire sale of refrigerators, companypressors and spare parts in 1964 was made to Spencer - Co. Ltd. at Delhi. Such transfers were accepted is genuine by the sales tax authorities.

facts.text: Appellant registered dealer under Punjab General Sales Tax Act 1948 and Central Sales Tax Act 1956 at Faridabad.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a registered dealer under the Punjab General Sales Tax Act, 1948 and the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956. The registration has been don-- at Faridabad.

facts.text: Factory went into production in 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The factory went into production in 1964.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to High Court on April 1, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: In the reference order dated April 1, 1971 the Sales Tax Tribunal while dealing with the transport of goods from Faridabad to Delhi observed

Section 6 of the Central Sales Tax Act  hereinafter referred to as the Act  makes every dealer liable for payment of tax under the Act on all sales effected by him in the course of inter-State trade or commerce.

concepts.interpretation: Makes every dealer liable for payment of tax on all sales effected by him in the course of inter-State trade or commerce.

A sale of goods can be held to have taken place in the course of inter-state trade under clause  a  of Section 3 of the Act if it can be shown that the sale has occasioned the movement of goods from one State to another.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case, the agreement between Ms. Kelvinator of India (Assessee), Ms. Spencer & Co. Ltd., Messrs Blue Star Engineering Co., and Ms. General Equipment Ltd., in pursuance of which the refrigerators manufactured by Ms. Kelvinator of India at Faridabad moved to Delhi were merely for distribution of goods between the principal and his agents or were agreements of sale between two parties?

General Equipment Ltd., in pursuance of which the refrigerators manufactured by M s, Kelvinator of India at Faridabad moved to Delhi were merely for distribution of goods between the principal and his agents or were agreements of sale between two parties?

holdings.text: The transactions in question do not amount to sales in the course of inter-State trade or commerce under the Central Sales Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: In the light of the principles enunciated above, it cannot in our opinions be said that the transactions in question amount to sale in the course of inter-state trade.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No contract of sale preceding movement; movement independent of any sale; lacks direct nexus required by s.3(a) CST Act as per Tata Iron and TELCO precedents.

holdings.text: The distribution agreements do not constitute contracts of sale.

anchor.surface_text: We are also unable to agree with the High Court that the distribution agreements constituted agreements of sale. It is noteworthy in this context to observe that the number of refrigerators which were to be purchased by each of the distributors was not specified in the distribution agreements,

holdings.reasoning_summary: No fixed quantity or price specified; framework for future mutual agreements on sales via specific orders placed after goods reach Delhi; actual contracts of sale formed later.

holdings.text: There was no appropriation of refrigerators to the contracts at Faridabad.

anchor.surface_text: The argument that the sale of refrigerators to each of the distributors took place at Faridabad and that it was at Faridabad that the refrigerators were appropriated towards the agreement with each of the three distributors appears to us to be not well-founded.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Refrigerators identical except interchangeable nameplates; no specific appropriation possible; orders placed post-movement in Delhi; no assent by distributors per s.23 Sale of Goods Act.

holdings.text: The movement of refrigerators from Faridabad to Delhi was not occasioned by any contract of sale or distribution agreement.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot, in our opinion, be said that there was any movement of refrigerators from Faridabad to Delhi under a contract of sale.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Goods moved routinely to own godown prior to specific orders; excise passes in self-favour; risk on company till Delhi delivery; analogous to TELCO stockyard transfers.

holdings.text: Sales took place in Delhi as local sales, with property passing there; no liability to pay Central Sales Tax.

anchor.surface_text: Looking to all the facts of the case, we have no doubt that the arrangement between the parties was that refrigerators would be sold by the appellant to the distributors after they had been transported to the sale office and godown of the appellant on Alipore Road, Delhi so that no liability to pay tax under the Act would arise.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Delivery, billing, payment, property passage in Delhi per agreements and course of dealings; movement inter-departmental for business convenience, not commercial under sale.

holdings.text: The appeal is allowed; High Court judgment set aside; question answered against department.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly accept the appeal and set aside the judgment of the High Court. The answer given by the High Court to the question referred to it is discharged.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative application of above holdings reverses lower courts' findings on nature of agreements and taxability.

holdings.text: Freight charges borne by distributors do not indicate movement occasioned by sale.

anchor.surface_text: The inclusion of the charges for the transport of the refrigerators from Faridabad to Delhi in the price payable by the distributors would not show that the movement of refrigerators from Faridabad to Delhi was occasioned by the contract of sale.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Transport charges part of ex-Delhi price calculation; sale/delivery expressly at Delhi; company bears risk till inspection at Delhi.

holdings.text: Section 23 of Sale of Goods Act does not apply as no unconditional appropriation with assent.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of assent by distributors; no authority to appropriate at Faridabad; revocable until orders placed.

precedents.citation: Tata Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. v. S. R. Sarkar and Ors.  1

anchor.surface_text: Tata Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. v. S. R. Sarkar and Ors.  1  Shah J.  as he then was  speaking for the majority observed that a transaction of sale is subject to tax under the Act on the completion of the sale.

precedents.case_name: Tata Iron and Steel Co. Ltd. v. S. R. Sarkar
precedents.cited_proposition: A mere contract of sale is not a sale within the definition of sale in section 2(g). A sale becomes taxable under section 3(a) if the movement of goods from one State to another is under a covenant or incident of the contract of sale.
precedents.cited_holding: a transaction of sale is subject to tax under the Act on the completion of the sale

precedents.citation: Ben Gorm Nilgiri Plantations Co. Cooncor Ors. v. Sales Tax Officer, Special Circle, Ernakulam Ors 2

anchor.surface_text: Ben Gorm Nilgiri Plantations Co. Cooncor Ors. v. Sales Tax Officer, Special Circle, Ernakulam Ors 2  this Court dealt with the provisions of section 5 of the Act which relates to sale or purchase of goods in the course of import or export.

precedents.case_name: Ben Gorm Nilgiri Plantations Co. v. Sales Tax Officer, Special Circle, Ernakulam
precedents.cited_proposition: A sale in the course of export predicates connection between the sale and export; the two activities being so integrated that the connection cannot be voluntarily interrupted without breach of contract or compulsion arising from the nature of the transaction; the export should be inextricably linked up with the sale.

precedents.citation: Tata Engineering Locomotive Co. Limited v. The Assistant Commissioner of Commercial Taxes Another  3

anchor.surface_text: Tata Engineering Locomotive Co. Limited v. The Assistant Commissioner of Commercial Taxes Another  3  and it was held that the sales to be exigible to tax under the Act must be shown to have occasioned the movement of goods or articles from one State to another

precedents.case_name: Tata Engineering Locomotive Co. Ltd. v. Assistant Commissioner of Commercial Taxes
precedents.cited_proposition: The sales to be exigible to tax under the Act must be shown to have occasioned the movement of goods from one State to another and that the movement must be the result of a covenant or incident of the contract of sale.

precedents.citation: Tata Engineering and Locomotive Co. Ltd. V. Assistant Commissioner of Commercial Taxes, Jamshedpur and Anr.  supra

anchor.surface_text: Tata Engineering and Locomotive Co. Ltd. V. Assistant Commissioner of Commercial Taxes, Jamshedpur and Anr.  supra . In that case the appellant company, which manufactured trucks and buses in Jamshedpur in the State of Bihar, transferred the vehicles to stock-yards

precedents.case_name: Tata Engineering and Locomotive Co. Ltd. v. Assistant Commissioner of Commercial Taxes, Jamshedpur
precedents.cited_proposition: The movement of vehicles from the works to the stock-yards was not occasioned by any covenant or incident of the contract of sale where there were no firm orders prior to movement, appropriation happened at stock-yards, and vehicles could be reallocated.
precedents.cited_holding: the procedure followed by the appellant together with the proved absence of any firm orders, indicated that the allocation letters [...] did not themselves bring about transactions of sale [...] it is not possible to comprehend how [...] the movement [...] was occasioned by any covenant or incident of the contract of sale.

justification_sets.label: Section 3(a), Central Sales Tax Act, 1956 support

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly accept the appeal and set aside the judgment of the High Court. The answer given by the High Court to the question referred to it is discharged. In our opinion, the three agreements between the appellant and the distributors were merely agreements for the distribution of goods and were number agreements of sale between the parties. It cannot, in our opinion, be said that there was any movement of refrigerators from Faridabad to Delhi under a companytract of sale.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal accepted and allowed; High Court judgment set aside; High Court's answer to the referred question discharged; distribution agreements held not to be contracts of sale; movement of goods not in course of inter-State trade; no tax liability under Central Sales Tax Act.
directions: Appellant entitled to costs from the respondent of this Court as well as in the High Court

anchor.surface_text: In the light of the principles enunciated above, it cannot in our opinions be said that the transactions in question amount to sale in the course of inter-state trade.

We accordingly accept the appeal and set aside the judgment of the High Court. The answer given by the High Court to the question referred to it is discharged. In our opinion, the three agreements between the appellant and the distributors were merely agreements for the distribution of goods and were number agreements of sale between the parties. It cannot, in our opinion, be said that there was any movement of refrigerators from Faridabad to Delhi under a companytract of sale.

anchor.surface_text: The argument that the sale of refrigerators to each of the distributors took place at Faridabad and that it was at Faridabad that the refrigerators were appropriated towards the agreement with each of the three distributors appears to us to be not well-founded.

We accordingly accept the appeal and set aside the judgment of the High Court. The answer given by the High Court to the question referred to it is discharged. In our opinion, the three agreements between the appellant and the distributors were merely agreements for the distribution of goods and were number agreements of sale between the parties. It cannot, in our opinion, be said that there was any movement of refrigerators from Faridabad to Delhi under a companytract of sale.
